original_data.question:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with the complaint of pain in his right toe for the past hour. The pain is so severe that it woke him up. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and binge drinks alcohol after work and on the weekends. He underwent an appendectomy when he was 14 years old. He is a long-distance truck driver. Neither of his parents had any significant medical history. His temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and BMI is 25 kg/m2. On examination, his right first metatarsophalangeal joint is very tender, swollen, warm, and red in color. Range of motion cannot be assessed due to extreme tenderness.
Laboratory test
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocytes 16,000/mm3
Platelets 150,000/mm3
ESR 50 mm/hr
Synovial fluid is aspirated from the joint. The findings are:
Appearance Cloudy, dense yellow
WBC 30,000 cells/µL
Culture Negative
Needle-shaped birefringent crystals are observed in the joint aspirate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s condition?

options.A: Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion

model_response:
The clinical and laboratory findings are consistent with acute gouty arthritis. The most common joint involved in the first attack of gout is the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The patient’s history of smoking, alcohol use, and surgery (appendectomy) are risk factors for gout. The presence of needle-shaped birefringent crystals (negatively birefringent) in the joint aspirate is diagnostic of gout. Hyperuricemia is not always present in gout, especially in the early stages. The most common causes of hyperuricemia are increased turnover of nucleic acids, obesity, and alcohol use. The treatment of choice for acute gout is NSAIDs.

Organic acids competing with urate for tubular secretion (Option A) is a mechanism of drug-induced hyperuricemia. Drugs that interfere with urate excretion are pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and diuretics.
Increased renal reabsorption of urate (Option B) is a mechanism of drug-induced hyperuricemia. Drugs that interfere with urate excretion are pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and diuretics.
Deficiency of HGPRT (Option C) is a cause of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by self-mutilation, choreoathetosis, spasticity, and mental retardation.
High-purine diet (Option D) is a risk factor for gout, but the patient’s history does not suggest a high-purine diet.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Drinking an excessive amount of ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES in a short period of time.
The time period comprising Saturday and Sunday, and sometimes considered to include Friday night.
Surgical removal of the vermiform appendix. (Dorland, 28th ed)
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
The visually perceived property of objects created by absorption or reflection of specific wavelengths of light.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
A dull achy pain.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
The determination of the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in a biospecimen.
The clear, viscous fluid secreted by the SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE. It contains mucin, albumin, fat, and mineral salts and serves to lubricate joints.
Also known as articulations, these are points of connection between the ends of certain separate bones, or where the borders of other bones are juxtaposed.

The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between orange and green, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 570 to 590 nanometers; any of a group of colors of a hue resembling that of ripe lemons and varying in lightness and saturation.
White blood cells. These include granular leukocytes (BASOPHILS; EOSINOPHILS; and NEUTROPHILS) as well as non-granular leukocytes (LYMPHOCYTES and MONOCYTES).
The fundamental, structural, and functional units or subunits of living organisms. They are composed of CYTOPLASM containing various ORGANELLES and a CELL MEMBRANE boundary.
Puncture and aspiration of fluid (e.g., SYNOVIAL FLUID) from a joint cavity. It is used sometimes to irrigate or administer drugs into a joint cavity.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
